The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in science. The most promising approach to their solution is to develop a mathematical theory that is able to capture the essence of the subject. In this paper, we provide a categorical foundation for quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. Our results provide a starting point for a theory of quantum computation and communication based on a categorical foundation. They also provide a foundation for the theory of quantum groups, which is a central object of study in mathematics and physics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with the Cnidaria, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related species of Myxozoa and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the Cnidaria and that the Myxozoan body plan is the result of a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, especially maize, which is the staple food of 35% of the world’s population. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability to quantify how maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the crisis on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are also financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses are planning to apply for the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with the application process.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global scale of the problem is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. However, the total amount of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of the debris, which is dominated by small particles, mostly below 1 mm. These particles are rapidly degraded into smaller particles, which are then transported to the ocean interior. This sink may be responsible for the missing plastic debris. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the plastic debris in the ocean. It also provides a reference for the future monitoring of the problem. This is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million more motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources. The expansion of the motorized fleet has been driven by the powered-artisanal fleet, which has grown substantially in recent decades. This sector is often overlooked in the reconstruction of the global fishing fleet. We provide a detailed reconstruction of the powered-artisanal fleet and its evolution since 1950. This sector has been underestimated in previous reconstructions.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all organisms. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing, where the mother provides care to her offspring. This suggests that the limiting factor in mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. We also find that domestication and all forms of allocare correlate with increased fertility. All forms of provisioning correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of parental care and domestication. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor prodrug VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study opens the way to a phase I/II clinical trial in MSA patients. This would be the first clinical trial in a synucleinopathy. The results of this trial would be of great importance to understand the pathophysiology of MSA and to develop new therapeutic strategies. This study also opens the way to the development of new therapeutic strategies in other synucleinopathies.

The vascular endothelium is the interface between the blood and the tissues. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. It also controls the contractility of the blood vessels and the blood flow. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also composed of a large number of specialized clusters of cells that are able to detect and integrate multiple lines of information. The nature of the communication network between the cells has not been well understood. Here, the nature of the communication network between the endothelial cells has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The results reveal that the communication network is a small-world network with a high degree of synchronizability. The small-world network is particularly effective for the efficient propagation of information and the rapid and robust communication between the endothelial cells. This is important for the control of the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has presented enormous data challenges. Epidemiological modelers, policy makers, and health researchers all require up-to-date data on the pandemic and relevant public behavior. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to fill this need. It provides open access to both traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the channel’s selectivity. It is also the most structurally conserved part of the channel. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the signature sequence of potassium channels as a crucial residue for the functional and structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have shown that this residue is responsible for the allosteric communication between the two gates. We have also shown that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the functional properties of potassium channels. It also provides a structural framework for the design of new drugs. This article is protected by copyright. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system, and the composition of the microbiome can change over time. The ability to manipulate the microbiome is therefore important for the development of new therapeutics. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products. These results support the use of anaerobic fungi as a source of natural products for the development of new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. It is established by the most aggressive and competitive individuals, who are able to maintain their position in the hierarchy. However, the mechanisms underlying social dominance are largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of developing social defeat, directly influences social dominance. We identify a key role for the brain region the nucleus accumbens in the mediation of this effect. We also provide evidence that the energy metabolism of this brain region is crucial for social dominance and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Here we show that the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway has a downstream element, the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), which can affect the hemoglobin content of human erythroblasts. This finding has implications for the understanding of the regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the association of LCCBs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of heart failure. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best candidate is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used acylide antibiotic, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The evolution of the African Great Lakes is a key component of the evolution of the African continent and its ecosystems. The evolution of Lake Malawi is particularly important as it is one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems on Earth. This study presents a 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the region, which is one of the most important controls on the evolution of the lake. The record shows a dramatic shift in the hydroclimate of the region at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, which is consistent with the global climate record. The record also shows that the evolution of the lake was controlled by a combination of climate and tectonic forcing. The evolution of the lake was also influenced by the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock, which is one of the most successful evolutionary events in the history of life on Earth. The evolution of the lake and the fish species flock was controlled by the same forcing mechanisms. This study shows that the evolution of the lake and the fish species flock were linked. This is important for understanding the evolution of the African continent and its ecosystems.

The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. However, the impact of this technology on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin, reduces the amount of sleep, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, but its role in the adult organism is not well understood. Here, we report that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in a variety of organs, including the lung, gut, and salivary glands. Moreover, we found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of Treg cell-mediated suppression. Our findings have important implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships and estimated the age of the order Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We found that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant-digesting enzymes. Our results suggest that beetle diversity resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant-digesting enzymes. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We manipulated population size such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Our results indicate that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the evolution of intelligence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is also known to influence the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We found that APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE isoform is highly dependent on APOE isoform. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, accelerating the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies may help to understand the pathophysiology of APOE4 and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 2,300 km, which is the deepest part of the Earth. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. This study shows that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more likely to occur than the nucleation of the stable hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the Earth. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is widely available, its effects on the brain are poorly understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors. The findings also highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana on the brain.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are the subject of intense study. Here, we use a state-of-the-art neural network model to make precise predictions about the brain’s neural responses to language. We find that the model’s neural predictions are strongly correlated with the model’s accuracy on a language comprehension task. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending language. They also suggest that the brain’s mechanisms for language comprehension are highly efficient, as the model achieves high accuracy with a simple architecture. This suggests that the brain may have evolved to perform predictive processing, and that the brain’s mechanisms for language comprehension may be highly similar across species. Together, these results provide a new perspective on the brain’s mechanisms for language comprehension. They also provide a powerful computational framework for future studies of the brain’s language mechanisms.

In this paper, we show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that it is not a universal approximator. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a network. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limitations of DL.

Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. The disease is characterized by progressive loss of sensation and disfigurement. The disease is difficult to treat and can be fatal. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and the genome is now only 2.6 Mb in size. Mycobacterium lepromatosis is a close relative of M. leprae, but the two are separated by 13.9 My. This study provides the first genome sequence for M. lepromatosis and reveals that the two species have retained many of the same functions. The two species are also remarkably similar in size, and the two have diverged only 1.1 My. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of the leprosy pathogen and may lead to the development of new treatments. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two pillars of quantum information theory, which is the main field of application of entanglement. The study of the evolution of entanglement is therefore a key step in the understanding of the thermodynamics of quantum systems. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nonlocal phenomenon, which makes its computation extremely difficult. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit for the study of thermodynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain. This allows us to provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. Our results are also relevant for the study of the thermodynamics of interacting systems.

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and pandemics. It is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis and can be transmitted by multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are bubonic, caused by spillover of infected fleas from rodent epizootics, or pneumonic, caused by inhalation of infectious droplets. However, little is known about the historical spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries), including the Black Death, which led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. Actin filaments are the major components of the cytoskeleton, which is essential for cell function. However, how it does so remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin binds more efficiently to filaments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced twist enhances severing by increasing the severing rate constant 100-fold. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for the function of ADF/cofilin in cells. They also provide a general framework for understanding the action of other proteins that bind to filaments in a twist-dependent manner. Emotional contagion is the process by which people experience the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the extent to which it occurs in the real world is unclear. We test the extent of emotional contagion in a large real-world social network by manipulating the amount of emotional content in the News Feed. We find that people produce fewer positive posts and more negative posts when positive content is reduced, and vice versa when negative content is reduced. These results suggest that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions, constituting experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread to 216 countries and territories, infecting millions of people and causing more than 400,000 deaths. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species of conservation concern in Iowa. They also highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2 in animal reservoirs. This understanding is critical for the development of effective control strategies.

The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. We demonstrate that neurons are the major source of cytokines and chemokines in the brain, and that the extent of the response correlates with the extent of neuronal damage. The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The brain is thought to build a hierarchical representation of sentences, but the neurophysiological evidence for this is still limited. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate the brain’s response to the unfolding of sentences. We found that the brain’s response to each word in a sentence was not constant, but increased with each successive word and decreased when words could be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity was consistent with a merge operation, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under increasing pressure from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate this pressure. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical component of climate-smart agriculture. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions. However, the genetic history of the population during the period of cultural change is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 490 and 620 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of the individuals is mostly of northern and central European origin, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. The RNA world hypothesis suggests that life may have originated without the involvement of proteins. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template. This polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplify RNA templates, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme can serve as a building block for the construction of an RNA-based cell. This work is a significant step toward the realization of the RNA world hypothesis.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays an important role in the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the tick microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) is expressed by Anaplasma phagocytophilum and is required for the efficient transmission of the pathogen to ticks. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the arthropod microbiota and may have implications for the control of vector-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the evolution of birds. The short-tailed bird group Pygostylia is a major evolutionary lineage that is thought to have contributed to the evolution of the modern avian bauplan. However, the known diversity of early branching members of Pygostylia is limited. Here, we describe a basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases our understanding of the evolution of the short-tailed bird group and its contribution to the evolution of the modern avian bauplan.

In this paper, we show that the atmosphere plays an important role in the evolution of our climate. Vertebrates have a wide variety of colors, which are often used to communicate with conspecifics and to avoid predation. In this study, we describe a new mechanism of color change in animals. The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 My, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization precedes the extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. This new age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. It will also provide a new time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a significant improvement over the previous best result, which only holds for games with finite action sets. It also provides a new proof of the existence of an ε-equilibrium in stochastic games. Our result is a step towards understanding the structure of repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate the impact of the pandemic on life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. Our projections indicate that the pandemic will result in a substantial decline in life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for Black and Latino Americans, and that the gap in life expectancy between Black and White Americans will increase. These projections have important implications for the future of the US health system and for the future of the country as a whole.

The chemical properties of an element are its reactivity and its affinity to other elements. These properties are fundamental to chemistry and are the basis of the periodic table. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of an element can be quantitatively described by two fundamental properties of an atom: electronegativity and chemical hardness. We show that these properties change with pressure, and that they can be used to predict and explain many chemical phenomena under pressure. This work is a step toward the development of a predictive theory of chemical phenomena under pressure. It also has implications for the development of a predictive theory of the behavior of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, which can have significant impacts on the carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of these impacts is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between fire, climate, and the carbon cycle. We show that changes in human demography can reduce the frequency of wildfires, which can reduce the magnitude of climate change. This effect is most pronounced under lower emissions scenarios, and it can reduce the projected global temperature increase by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. Our results highlight the importance of human-driven changes in fire regimes in the context of climate change. This is important for policy makers and land managers, as well as for understanding the impacts of climate change on human societies.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the growth and health of their microbial partners. Chitin is released by the host only at night, when the symbiont population is at its highest, and is required for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which increases the availability of oxygen to the symbionts. The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of the Black Death in Europe in 1347 CE, lasted for four centuries. This event is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This finding challenges the traditional view of the Black Death and its aftermath and opens up new perspectives on the history of the plague. Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, the population dynamics of asteroid species have recently been affected by a disease that has led to rapid degradation of the animals. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a disease of marine invertebrates. The virus is widespread in the environment and has been present in asteroids for at least 72 y. This suggests that the disease is a major threat to the functioning of coastal ecosystems.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is important for the development of more efficient therapies. Furthermore, we show that the antibody can also suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to accomplish this, including the storage of information in the form of persistent activity. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in photosynthesis, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. A diiron enzyme from a betaproteobacterium is required for cyanobacterial function, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a protein encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Astrocyte-specific ASK1 deletion was achieved using a CX3CR1CreER system, and we found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. We also find that the probability of drought has increased when precipitation deficits are combined with warm conditions. This finding is consistent with the hypothesis that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. Thus, the human-caused warming of the climate system is increasing the probability of drought. This finding has important implications for water resources management and for the design of drought response strategies. Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the autism-risk genes and their functions and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This study also provides a useful model system for the study of the underlying mechanisms of behavioral flexibility. (Show more)

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and a Stormorken-like syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation and aggregation of misfolded proteins. The mechanisms underlying the propagation of these aggregates and their role in disease progression are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires active endocytosis and that the release of aggregates is important for disease progression. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the propagation of neurodegenerative aggregates and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the evolution of land plants. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants, and the origin of this group is poorly understood. The study of the early evolution of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils. Here we present a detailed description of Montsechia, a flowering plant from the Cretaceous. The study of this plant, together with the description of other Cretaceous flowering plants, opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the evolution of the flowering plants.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that are responsible for a number of diseases in humans. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from living species, but the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is unknown. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses lived ∼12.6 thousand years ago, and that the recombination event that formed the human-associated parvovirus genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and it is rising because of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise due to climate change, which is 2.9 mm/y, and a projection of how sea level will rise in the future. This study also provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise due to natural causes, which is 1.3 mm/y. This study provides a more accurate estimate of sea level rise than previous studies, and it provides a more accurate estimate of natural sea level rise than previous studies. Pain is a major public health problem, with the elderly reporting more pain than younger adults. However, in America today, midlife Americans report less pain than do the elderly. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain. Tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction transition state is a critical determinant of reaction rate and specificity. The structure of the enzyme-bound reaction intermediate is therefore a key target for mechanistic enzymology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The structure of this intermediate is used to understand the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state, and to explain why the natural substrate indole, but not benzimidazole, is unable to react. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the growth and health of their microbial partners. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is released by the host only at night, when the symbiont population is at its highest, and is required for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which increases the availability of oxygen to the symbionts. This glycan is thus used as a cue to synchronize the activities of the host and symbiont. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of how host-derived nutrients are used to regulate the activities of symbiotic microbes. It also suggests that other hosts may use similar strategies to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. (Show more)

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food system also contributes to the burden of diet-related disease, the leading cause of death globally. Changing the food system is a major challenge, but it is possible to make a start by changing the food choices of people in higher-income countries. This paper reports the results of a large-scale field experiment and observational study that shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 100% led to a 60% increase in the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased. This is a substantial contribution to the challenge of changing the food system. The results also suggest that it is possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets without the need for complex interventions. This is an important finding for policy makers and practitioners.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a dynamic and complex system. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward understanding the surfaceome in normal and cancer cells. It is also a first step toward understanding the surfaceome in other cell types and tissues. This work is also a first step toward understanding the glycoproteome in normal and cancer cells.

In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic. This paper is a call to action for election administrators to implement vote-by-mail programs in the future. (Show more)

This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, and the presence of this interface may contribute to the immune evasion and immune suppression activities of the virus. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. The world is full of associations. We are interested in finding the strongest ones. But we are also interested in the strength of all the associations. In the era of big data, it is important to be able to assess the strength of all the associations. We describe some recent developments in this area. We show how to do selective inference in stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We illustrate the use of these methods with a real data set.

In this study, we identified the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a direct inducer of vascular ECs. The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling receptors that are involved in a variety of physiological processes. In the last few years, two new ligands for RTKs were discovered. We also show that these ligands are important for the differentiation of neural crest-derived cells into iridophores. This work establishes a physiological link between the RTKs and their ligands. It also provides a model system for studying the function of RTKs and their ligands in vivo. This work may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer and other diseases.

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States. This increase has led to substantial economic and ecological costs. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that the human-caused fire season is three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season. We also show that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occur in areas where fuel moisture is higher than lightning-caused fires. These findings highlight the importance of reducing the risk of human-caused wildfires to reduce the economic and ecological costs of wildfire.

Urban change is a major topic of urban studies. However, the physical dynamics of urban change are difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work also provides a proof of concept for a new urban data science field: the study of urban change using computer vision methods and street-level imagery. This field is likely to grow rapidly in the coming years.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the main site of nutrient absorption and the first line of defense against infections. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost, and the adult nervous system is unable to repair itself after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration is a powerful platform for the discovery of new mechanisms controlling the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Moreover, they suggest that the adult nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought. This study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This work may lead to the development of new strategies for the repair of the adult nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired. It is essential for the proper development of the organism and the maintenance of the genome. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The hotspots are similar to those found in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the mechanisms of recombination described here may be ancient and conserved. This work provides a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, which is an important model for studying the evolution of recombination. It also provides a resource for studying the genetic architecture of recombination in a flowering plant. This work will be useful for many fields of biology.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a number of networks, which are topographically and functionally distinct. Here, we used metabolic PET to identify and validate the dominant resting state network in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting state network was topographically similar to the default mode network in healthy subjects. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant resting state network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant resting state network was deactivated during rest and activated during task performance. This abnormality was reduced in advanced Parkinson’s disease, and time-course comparisons of dominant resting state network loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for Parkinson’s disease, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. The 5′ end of many RNAs is modified by a cap structure, which is a methylated guanosine residue. Here we describe a second cap structure, a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that the NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally and is not found on pre-mRNAs. This finding suggests that the NAD+ cap may have a role in regulating the stability and translation of specific subsets of mRNAs. The discovery of the NAD+ cap in eukaryotes may have implications for understanding the function of this modification in bacteria.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes persist for several years after the end of the study. These DNA-me differences are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Our results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of metabolic memory and may help to develop new strategies to improve the treatment of people with diabetes. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a possible explanation for the high mortality rate of alcohol dependence. The results may also have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies. Tomato fruit are a major source of food flavor, and the quality of the flavor is determined by the composition of the volatile organic compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not well understood, and the only known nitrogenous volatiles are derived from cysteine. This study identifies a gene essential for the production of all the known nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also provides a model for the biosynthesis of other nitrogenous volatiles in plants. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have implications for the design of biodiversity conservation strategies and the management of ecosystems under global warming. This article is protected by copyright. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It encodes the spatial layout of the environment, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to be specialized for different aspects of navigation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of MEC neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a mental map of the environment, are anatomically distinct from other cell types and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings have implications for our understanding of the formation of spatial representations in the brain. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This is an example of a unique form of interplant communication, which is likely to be important for the synchronization of flowering time.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized, highly unusual form of arborization of striatonigral fibers, which are the major source of dopamine to the striatum. These striosome–dendron bouquets are formed by striatonigral fibers that originate in striosomes and target clusters of dopamine-containing dendrites and their parent cell bodies in the ventral tegmental area. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This discovery has implications for understanding the function of the dopamine systems in health and disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

We are social creatures, and we often judge the quality of our social interactions by how connected we feel. But how do we know when we are feeling connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed of communication is a robust signal of connection. We found that people felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. This signal was used by third-party listeners to judge the quality of the connection between two people. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs), which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and its function is tightly regulated. Here, we report that the store-operated Ca2+ entry channel STIM1 is expressed in SANCs and is required for their function. We show that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of SANCs by controlling the activity of a store-operated Ca2+ current and the L-type Ca2+ current. Our results reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the regulation of the electrical activity of SANCs. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms governing the function of the SAN. It also has implications for the treatment of heart failure, which is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest, in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis and perception genes. This interaction between Si and JA was associated with priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect rice plants against insect herbivores by priming JA-mediated defense responses. This strategy may be applicable to other crops. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages. Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to accomplish this, but the mechanisms are not well understood. Here we propose a model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on a variety of timescales, including milliseconds, seconds, and even minutes. This mechanism is not based on the storage of spikes, and it does not rely on feedback or plasticity. Instead, it is based on the reduction of firing rates and the storage of information in the dynamics of the adaptive conductances that control the levels of inhibition. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also provides a mechanism for the temporal integration of linguistic information.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic stimuli. Thus, they have evolved a number of defense mechanisms to protect themselves from pathogens. One such mechanism is the production of siRNAs, which are then used to trigger the immune response. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of new strategies for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient inputs to coastal ecosystems are often dominated by small tributaries, but their importance has been overlooked. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large water bodies. We found that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan accounted for 70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone, increasing the likelihood of coastal eutrophication. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in coastal nutrient cycling and provide a framework for future efforts to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. The study of the dynamics of complex systems is a central theme in modern science. In this article, we study the dynamics of a simple model system, a chemical network, in a highly nonthermal environment. We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environment. This finding has implications for the study of the dynamics of complex systems in general.

The mechanisms by which the immune system can cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of an autoimmune encephalitis can change the dynamics of the brain, making it more susceptible to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We show that the immune response can change the dynamics of the brain, making it more susceptible to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This is likely to be a common mechanism in autoimmune encephalitis, and may explain why the same antibodies can cause different syndromes. This mechanism may also explain the effects of other immune responses, such as those caused by viral encephalitis. This work offers mechanistic insights into the mechanisms of immune-mediated seizures. It may also lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid warming event. To understand the causes and consequences of such events, it is important to understand the history of abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global-scale organic matter–derived carbon perturbation and an increase in atmospheric CO2. We also show that the warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. Our results provide insights into the causes and consequences of rapid warming events and can help us to better understand the current rapid warming. This article is protected by copyright. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced tropical forest loss in Indonesia by 33%. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies to reduce tropical deforestation. Our findings also highlight the importance of certification in forested regions, where most remaining forests are located. Our results are important for the palm oil industry, policy makers, and certification organizations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of the complex is conserved across species. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a key factor in its fitness. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, sex determination is polygenic, and the sex of an individual can be determined by more than one sex determination allele. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two sex determination alleles produce four possible sexes. We find that polygenic sex determination results in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the introgression of a newly acquired sex determination allele creates additional axes of variation for secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, a class of oxidized carotenoids, and their degradation products. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in retinal pigment epithelial cells, promote the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the reduction of iron levels may be a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of this blinding disease. This strategy may also be applicable to other retinal diseases, such as retinitis pigmentosa. (Read more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of predator specialization is a fundamental process in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are often lost during the evolution of more generalized predators. Here we show that this is not the case for siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators that have evolved a modular prey-capture system. We show that siphonophore specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our findings help to understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a new perspective on the evolution of predator specialization.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the hand is incomplete, however, and the earliest hominin fossils are incomplete. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from 1.42 My old sediments in Kenya. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding also suggests that the evolution of the human hand was more complex than previously thought. The implications of this finding for the evolution of the human hand are discussed. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2). We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the inhibitor is effective in B-cell lines, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a metabolic target for the treatment of DLBCL. It also provides a rationale for the use of the inhibitor in B-cell lines. It also provides a rationale for the use of the inhibitor in B-cell malignancies. It also provides a rationale for the use of the inhibitor in B-cell malignancies.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that natural landscapes such as forests can contribute to meeting these goals. We show that deforestation in rural Tanzania led to a reduction in people’s fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, we found that forest fragmentation led to an increase in consumption of these foods and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also provides a model for how to conduct causal analyses of this type. This is a first step toward understanding the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it comes at a cost of soil degradation. Soil compaction is a major threat to soil functioning, with the potential to reduce crop yields by 20%. We show that the mechanization of agriculture has led to the propagation of compaction into deeper soil layers, with the risk of subsoil compaction now affecting 20% of arable land. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery, which should be lighter and smaller, and for a better understanding of the intrinsic mechanical limits of the soil.
